titleStmt.title: Identification, characterization and prevalence in southern China of a new iflavirus in the leafhopper Recilia dorsalis (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae)

analytic.title: Identification, characterization and prevalence in southern China of a new iflavirus in the leafhopper Recilia dorsalis (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae)

textClass.keywords: Recilia dorsalis iflavirus 2 Leafhopper Phylogenetic relationships Geographic distribution

p.s: The leafhopper Recilia dorsalis (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) is not only a significant pest in agriculture but also an important vector involved in transmitting numerous pathogens that are known to cause economic losses by affecting rice crops.
Here, a new iflavirus was discovered in the leafhopper R. dorsalis by employing a transcriptomic approach.

The complete viral genome was determined to be 10,711 nucleotides (nt) in length and contains a single open reading frame (ORF) encoding a putative polyprotein comprised of 3,161 amino acids (aa), which is flanked by 5 ′ and 3 ′ untranslated regions.
The full viral genome nt and the deduced polyprotein aa sequence showed the highest similarity (71.6% and 77.8%, respectively) with Langfang leafhopper iflavirus.

Phylogenetic analysis based on the RdRp domain indicated that the isolated virus, which we have tentatively named Recilia dorsalis iflavirus 2 (RdIV2), is clustered with the members of the family Iflaviridae.

Moreover, the results of our surveys indicate that RdIV2 predominates in southwestern Guangdong and southeastern Guangxi, China, and was absent in the other three species of leafhoppers; Nephotettix cincticeps, N. virescens and N. nigropictus.

Notably, R. dorsalis was found to be co-infected with RdIV2 and rice stripe mosaic virus (RSMV; a well-known rice-infecting virus vectored by R. dorsalis) in rice fields, although the co-infection rate is low.
Insects comprise the largest and most diverse group of multicellular organisms on earth, acting as important vectors of numerous viruses infecting humans, animals, and plants.

Most insect viruses have been intentionally isolated and characterized because they directly exert pathogenic effects on their hosts or because they cause diseases in other species (Nouri et al., 2018).

However, with the ongoing development of meta-genomics, meta-transcriptomic next-generation sequencing and bioinformatics, numerous viruses that produce covert infections have also been discovered after being identified from by metatranscriptomics of insects without any external indications of infection (Shi et al., 2016).
Iflaviruses have single-stranded, positive-sense, non-segmented RNA genomes of approximately 9-11 kilobases, and belong to the family Iflaviridae under the order Picornavirales (Valles et al., 2017).
The typical protein arrangement exists in the order VP2-VP3-VP1-Helicase-Protease-RdRp (Van Oers, 2010;Valles et al., 2017).
In some iflaviruses, such as infectious flacherie virus, a fourth capsid protein named VP4 (4-12 kDa) is present between VP2 and VP3.
This protein is analogous to the VP4 protein of members of the family Dicistroviridae (also in the order Picornavirales).
Currently, the family Iflaviridae is comprised of a single genus, Iflavirus, which contains 16 species (Valles et al., 2017).
To date, all reported iflaviruses have been isolated from arthropod hosts, particularly insects (Valles et al., 2017).

As of August 2022, eight iflaviruses have been reported to have leafhoppers as hosts: Recilia dorsalis iflavirus 1 (Ma et al., 2022), Lycorma delicatula iflavirus 1 (Wang et al., 2022), Exitianus capicola iflavirus 2 (Ye et al., 2022), Cicadella viridis iflavi-rus1 (Li et al., 2022), Langfang leafhopper iflavirus (Khine et al., 2020), Psammotettix alienus iflavirus 1 (Wang et al., 2019), Euscelidius variegates virus 1 (Abba et al., 2017), and Graminella nigrifrons virus 1 (Chen et al., 2015).
Recilia dorsalis (Hemiptera: Cicadellidae) is a common pest widely distributed in Asia.

R. dorsalis can damage rice plants via their direct ingestion and transmit plant pathogens, such as Rice gall dwarf virus (Chen et al., 2013), Rice stripe mosaic virus (Yang et al., 2017b;Zhao et al., 2019), and Rice orange leaf phytoplasma (Hibino et al., 1987;Lin et al., 1983).
In the present study, we identified a new iflavirus from R. dorsalis by transcriptome sequencing.
Then, we characterized its viral genome, phylogenetic relationships and geographical distribution.

In order to distinguish Recilia dorsalis iflavirus 1, which has been reported to reside on R. dorsalis (Ma et al., 2022), we named this virus Recilia dorsalis iflavirus 2 (RdIV2), and classifying it as a new member of the genus Iflavirus of the family Iflaviridae.
R. dorsalis adult leafhoppers were collected from a rice field as previously described (Yang et al., 2017a), and reared over three generations subsisting on healthy rice plants (Oryza sativa L. cv.
"Nipponbare") with four-leaf stages.
A second set of samples were collected from Jun 2018 to Nov 2021.

A total of 1181 adult leafhoppers belonging to four species (R. dorsalis, Nephotettix cincticeps, N. virescens and N. nigropictus) were collected from rice fields across four provinces (Guangdong, Guangxi, Hu'nan, and Hainan) in southern China (Table 1).
The leafhoppers were maintained within insect-proof cages in a climate chamber kept at 25 • C and 80% relative humidity under a 16 h light/8 h dark photoperiod.

div.head: RNA extraction and virus genome sequencing

p.s: A total number of 300 newly emerged adult leafhopper R. dorsalis samples was sent to Novogene (Beijing, China) for transcriptome sequencing.
The total RNA of R. dorsalis was extracted from a pooled sample containing 100 adult leafhoppers using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen, California, United States).
The total amount and integrity of the obtain RNA were assessed using the RNA Nano 6000 Assay Kit of the Bioanalyzer 2100 system (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA).
Then, mRNA was purified from the total RNA by using poly-T oligo-attached magnetic beads (Novogene, Beijing, China).

Reverse transcription reactions (1 μg of total RNA per sample) were performed using the TransScript One-Step gDNA Removal and cDNA Synthesis SuperMix Kit (TransGen Biotech, Beijing, China) according to the manufacturer's instructions.
The synthesized cDNA was then amplified as a template using the polymerase chain reaction (PCR).
Transcriptome sequencing was performed by Novogene (Beijing, China) using three independent RNA libraries (each library contained 100 adult insects).
Briefly, in order to preferentially select cDNA fragments 370-420 bp in length, the library fragments were purified using the AMPure XP system (Beckman Coulter, Beverly, USA).

Then PCR amplification was performed, the product was purified by AMPure XP beads, and the product was finally sequenced using the RNA-Seq by Illumina HiSeq platform 4000 (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA).

After sequencing, raw data (raw reads) in the fastq format were quality trimmed for adaptor sequences, and the clean reads were used for de novo assembly using Trinity (Grabherr et al., 2011) using the default parameters.
In order to identify the virus-like contigs, the assembled contigs were subjected to a BLASTx search using the NCBI databases.
To obtain the complete viral genome sequence from the transcriptome assembled sequence, we performed RNA ligase-mediated rapid amplification of cDNA end (RLM-RACE) (Liu and Gorovsky, 1993).
The 5 ′ and 3 ′ ends of the viral genome were determined using the viral cDNA and viral RNA after ligating their 3 ′ ends with an adaptor and oligo T primer, respectively.
The obtained viral genome was confirmed by RT-PCR and then completely sequenced.
All primers used in this study are listed in Supplementary Table S1.
Both the nucleotide sequence analysis and assembly of the virus genome were performed using the Vector NTI (Li and Moriyama, 2004) software.
The open reading frame (ORF) of the viral genome was predicted using the ORF finder tool on the NCBI website (http://www.ncbi. nlm.nih.gov/gorf/gorf.html).
The nucleotide (nt) and putative amino acid (aa) sequences were aligned with other iflaviruses using the Clustal W program (Thompson et al., 1994).
The conserved domains of the aa sequence were predicted using the Conserved Domain Database tool on the NCBI website (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Structure/cdd/ wrpsb.cgi)
and the online InterPro tool (http://www.ebi.ac.uk/ interpro/).

A phylogenetic tree was constructed from the deduced aa sequences of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase domain (RdRP) using the neighbor-joining method with a bootstrap of 1000 replicates in MEGA 11 (Tamura et al., 2021).

div.head: Prevalence of RdIV2 in leafhopper populations in southern China

p.s: Total RNA was isolated from individual insects using Trizol reagent (Vazyme, Nanjing, China).
RT-PCR amplification was carried out using the One-Step RNA PCR Kit (Takara, Dalian, China) and virus-specific detection primers (Supplementary Table S1) were used to detect RdIV2.

The following RT-PCR program was used: 50 • C for 30 min, and 94 • C for 2 min, followed by 35 cycles of 94 • C for 30 s, 55 • C for 30 s and 72 • C for 30 s, and a final extension of 72 • C for 5 min.
The PCR products were then excised from 1.2% agarose gel after electrophoresis and subsequently sequenced for analysis.
To investigate the prevalence of RdIV2 in R. dorsalis field populations, insects were collected from different locations across south China during 2018-2021 (Table 1).
Individual insects were analyzed by RT-PCR.

div.head: Genome characteristics of the novel Recilia dorsalis iflavirus

p.s: One viral sequence (10,691 nt) was initially identified from the transcriptomes of R. dorsalis.

Conducting a BLASTx search against the NCBI database revealed that the sequence had the highest similarity to the Langfang leafhopper iflavirus, with a 75.48% sequence identity, and 83.00% coverage of the Langfang leafhopper iflavirus genome sequence.

The full genomic sequence of RdIV2 (GenBank accession number OP649595) was determined to be 10,711 nt in length without the poly (A) tail and contains one large ORF (1,132-10,617 nt) which putatively encodes a polyprotein of 3161 aa that is flanked by untranslated region (UTR).
The 5 ′ UTR is 1131 nt in length and contains 13 AUG triplets.
The 3 ′ UTR is 94 nt in length and is located at positions nt 10,618-10,711 (Fig. 1A).

The nucleotide base composition of the viral genome was 29.12%A, 20.46% G, 32.51% U, and 17.91%C with an A/U richness similar to that of other iflaviruses (the A + U and G + C content were 61.63% and 38.37%, respectively).

The genomic nt sequence identities and the polyprotein aa sequence identities between RdIV2 and those of other iflaviruses ranged from 32.1% to 71.6% and 12.3% to 77.8%, respectively (Supplementary Table S2).

div.head: RdIV2 genome organization and comparison with other iflaviruses

p.s: The genome of RdIV2 has the typical iflavirus organization, with a structural module composed of VP2-VP3-VP1 followed by a nonstructural (replication-associated) module composed of Hel-Pro-RdRp (Fig. 1).

Conserved domain analysis revealed conserved domains in the structural proteins of iflaviruses (including RdIV2), which are analogous to those identified for other iflaviruses, and identified the recognized conserved domains in the replication-associated proteins.

In addition, a disordered site was predicted for RdIV2 at aa position 933-966 (upstream of the VP1 coding region), and two transmembrane domains were predicted at the aa positions 1308-1331 and 2265-2282 in the Hel and Pro coding regions, respectively (Fig. 1).
The three conserved capsid protein of RdIV2 were identified at aa positions 234-469 (VP2), 494-744 (VP3), and 935-1192 (VP1) (Fig. 1).

In VP2, the picornavirus conserved motif NxNxFQxG was observed in all iflavirus capsid proteins (Fig. 2), and a 24 aa long conserved motif WxGxLx4DxVx4HxGx5YxP, which is also analogous to that of picornavirus, was identified in VP3 (Fig. 2).
Finally, the picornavirus conserved motif FxRG was identified in VP1 (Fig. 2).
The RdIV2 replication-associated proteins contained three conserved domains that are known to be present in other iflaviruses and many other +ssRNA viruses.
The helicase protein contained three conserved motifs: Hel-A (GxPGxGKS), Hel-B (QPx4DD), and Hel-C (PPxAxxEDK) (Fig. S1).
The conserved cysteine protease motif (GxCG) and substratebinding motif (GxHxAG) were observed in the protease (Fig. S1).
Eight characteristic motifs in the RdRp domain were identified, including the highly conserved motif VI (YGDD) which represents the catalytic center (Fig. S1).

div.head: Phylogenetic relationships between RdIV2 and known iflaviruses

p.s: To reveal the relationship between RdIV2 and other known iflaviruses, we constructed phylogenetic trees of the conserved RdRp region aa sequences.
Sixteen classified members and 18 unclassified species in the family Iflaviridae and the other species in families Secoviridae and Picornaviridae were selected for analysis.

Based on the generated phylogenetic tree, RdIV2 appears to be a new member of the family Iflaviridae, and is most closely related to Langfang leafhopper iflavirus which is also found in leafhopper Psammotettix alienus (Fig. 3).

In addition, viruses that infect hosts of the same order were found to segregate into different clades, suggesting that the iflaviruses do not strictly follow evolutionary relationships with their hosts.
Furthermore, aa identities ranged from 12.3% to 77.8% among the polyprotein sequence of the other iflaviruese (Supplementary Table S2), which were lower than the species demarcation criterion (90%).
GenBank accession numbers of the iflaviruses sequences used for comparisons and phylogenetic analyses are given in Supplementary Table S2.

div.head: Prevalence of RdIV2 in different geographical regions

p.s: To evaluate the current distribution and incidence of RdIV2, a total of 658 R. dorsalis individuals were collected from four provinces (Guangdong, Guangxi, Hainan and Hunan) in southern China from Jun 2018 to Nov 2021 (Table 1).
The results showed that RdIV2 was commonly found in R. dorsalis populations with infection rates ranging from 3.33% to 28.00% (Table 1).

In the Guangdong and Guangxi populations, the average R. dorsalis infection rates were 17.28% (61/353) and 9.24% (18/191), respectively, while the Hainan (5.97%, 4/67) and Hu'nan (4.26%, 2/47) populations displayed lower rates of prevalence.
RdIV2 was found to mainly occurs in southwestern Guangdong and southeastern Guangxi and was also observed in central parts of Hainan (Fig. 4).

Moreover, RdIV2 was not detected in the other sampled leafhoppers, namely N. cincticeps (288 individuals), N. virescens (64 individuals) and N. nigropictus (171 individuals), thereby indicating that RdIV2 is mainly prevalent in R. dorsalis (Table 1).
Notably, some insect samples were also found to be co-infected with RdIV2 and RSMV (a wellknown rice-infecting virus vectored by R. dorsalis) in rice fields.

The RdIV2 and RSMV co-infection rate was 2.27% (8/353), 1.57% (3/191) and (1.49%, 1/67) in the Guangdong, Guangxi and Hainan populations, respectively, while undetected in the Hu'nan populations (Table 1).
Iflaviruses exist ubiquitously in insect hosts and several new iflaviruses have been discovered by the increasing use of high-throughput RNA sequencing technology.
In this study, transcriptome sequencing and RT-PCR were performed to acquire the full genome of a new insect virus.

Based on its genome organization, sequence alignments, and phylogenetic relationships with other iflaviruses, we identified the virus to be a new iflavirus in the family Iflaviridae, and we named this virus Recilia dorsalis iflavirus 2.
The conserved motifs NxNxFQxG, WxGxLx3FxFx7Gx5YxP, and FxRG have previously been identified within the picornavirus structural proteins VP2, VP3, and VP1, respectively (Liljas et al., 2002).
In this study, the conserved motif WxGxLx4DxVx4HxGx5YxP of VP3 (Fig. 2) was found to be divergent from that of the previous study to some extent (Jia et al., 2021;Wu et al., 2019).

Three conserved motifs in the helicase domain (A, B, and C) were identified (Fig. S1), and these were similar to those of previous reports from the consensus sequence KGx4Sx5STN (Gorbalenya and Koonin, 1989).

Furthermore, two conserved motifs GxCG (Ryan and Flint, 1997) and a substrate-binding motif GxHxx3G (Gorbalenya et al., 1989) found within the cysteine-protease were also observed within this region (Fig. S1).
The highly conserved motif YGDD found in RdRp (Fig. S1) is a characteristic motif of the RdRp domain in positive-strand RNA viruses (Koonin et al., 1993).
From the phylogenetic analysis conducted on the RdRp domain, the result indicates that iflaviruses have not strictly co-evolved with their hosts (Fig. 3).

For example, bat iflavirus is located next to the slow bee paralysis virus phylogenetically and is more closely related to iflaviruses, which suggests that the iflaviruses found in bat feces might be dietarily derived from the consumption of infected insects (Yinda et al., 2017).
Like plant viruses, some iflaviruses have host specificity, whereby they can only be naturally isolated from only one or a few closely related insect species.

For instance, Nephotettix cincticeps positive-stranded RNA virus-1 can infect N. cincticeps, with a relatively lower infection rate in N. apicalis, but it was not detected in R. dorsalis (Jia et al., 2021).

A new iflavirus known as, Laodelphax striatellus iflavirus 1 was found in L. striatella, but failed to be detected in two other planthopper species Sogatella furcifera and Nilaparvata lugens (Wu et al., 2019).
Spodoptera exigua iflavirus was reported to be present in S. exigua, but was not detected in S. frugiperda (Millan-Leiva et al., 2012).
However, cross-species infection also has been reported for some iflaviruses.
For instance, Dos Santos et al. (2019) reported that the Halyomorpha halys virus was isolated from four stink bugs of different species by transcriptomes.
Moku virus is a newly discovered iflavirus found in wasps, honey bees, and Varroa, thereby suggesting that the virus can infect both hymenopteran and Acari hosts (Mordecai et al., 2016).
In a similar case, Deformed wing virus was discovered in both bumble bees (Genersch et al., 2006) and a small hive beetle (Eyer et al., 2009).
In this study, the closely related species N. cincticeps, N. virescens and N. nigropictus were also investigated as potential hosts for RdIV2.
However, the virus could not be detected in these species (Table 1), which indicates that they may not serve as the natural hosts of RdIV2.
Whether other rice insects (primarily planthoppers) sever as additional hosts will require further experimental evidence.
Co-infection is a common phenomenon observed in iflaviruses, where two infecting pathogens establish a successful infection in the host.

For example, two insect-specific viruses Cicadella viridis iflavirus 1 and Cicadella viridis nido-like virus 1 were discovered in the green leafhopper Cicadella viridis, and each was found to be targeted by host antiviral RNAi (Li et al., 2022).

Furthermore, co-infection with iflavirus and baculovirus was found to be beneficial for the survival of iflavirus in Spodoptera exigua by increasing the physical stability and infectivity of the infecting iflavirus (Jakubowska et al., 2016).
In another study, susceptibility to Spodoptera exigua nucleopolyhedrovirus infection in Spodoptera exigua was found to increase in the presence of iflavirus (Carballo et al., 2020).
In contrast, a novel iflavirus infection was found to be inhibited by RDV in the N. cincticeps (Jia et al., 2021).

In the present study, RdIV2 was present in co-infection with RSMV (a well-known pathogen that causes disease in rice; Yang et al., 2017a) in the fields, but RSMV was found to have a higher infection rate than RdIV2 (Table 1).

Additional, field investigations indicate that RdIV2 is now mainly distributed in southeastern Guangxi and the southwestern Guangdong Province of China (Fig. 4), where RSMV disease incidence has been occurring at an increased rate (Wang et al., 2021).

Given that the co-infection rates of RdIV2 and RSMV were found to be lower than that of RdIV2 alone among field populations (Table 1), the results implicate that RSMV may have an antagonizing effect on RdIV2 infection.
Additionally, whether there exists a direct or indirect interaction between RdIV2 and RSMV requires further study.
Iflaviruses are known to cause overt and covert infections, the latter of which appear to be common.
Covert infections are characterized by the virus maintaining general harmony with the host by not significantly impairing the host's adaptive capacity.
In the case of RdIV2, neither obvious symptoms nor negative effects are caused in R. dorsalis (data not shown).
Therefore, RdIV2 has the potential to be engineered and modified into a vector to deliver genes of interest in insects.
Further research will be needed to confirm the validity of this potential future application of the virus.
In conclusion, this study reports a novel iflavirus isolated from the leafhopper R. dorsalis and named RdIV2.
Molecular characterization and phylogenetic analysis indicated that RdIV2 is a novel member of the genus Iflavirus.
RdIV2 was found to be co-infected with RSMV in the obtained field leafhopper populations.

Further investigation on hostpathogen interactions, protein function, and immune responses should be conducted to help fully understand RdIV2 infection and provide new possibilities for the pest management in the future.
Fig. 1.
A schematic diagram of RdIV2 genome organization.
Fig. 2. Protein domain alignments of structural proteins of RdIV2 among the other iflaviruses.
The amino acids shaded in red and shadow red indicate the conservative and similar residues, respectively.
Numbers in the up of the sequences refer to the amino acid positions from the N-terminus of the viral polyprotein.
Fig. 3. Phylogenetic analyses using the RdRP amino acid sequences from 41 viruses in the order Picornavirales.
The phylogenetic tree was constructed from the deduced RNA-dependent RNA polymerase domain by neighbor-joining method based on poisson model.
Bootstrap support (%) based on 1000 bootstrap replicates is shown above and below nodes.
RdIV2V is labeled with a black circle, and the classified species in the genus Iflavirus are labeled with black triangles.
The natural hosts of the known iflaviruses are listed to the right of iflavirus name.
Fig. 4. Geographic distribution of RdIV2 in southern China during 2018 and 2021.
The infectivity rate (%) of RdIV2, RSMV and co-infection rate (%) of RdIV2 with RSMV in different leafhopper from different locations in South China.

row.cell: Co-infection rate of RdIV2 with RSMV

Fig. S1.
Protein domain alignments of non-structural proteins comprising RdIV2 among other iflaviruses.
The amino acids shaded in red and light red indicate the conservative and similar residues, respectively.
Numbers in the up of the sequences refer to the amino acid positions from the N-terminus of the viral protein.
No data was used for the research described in the article.

I would like to declare on behalf of my co-authors that the work described was original research that has not been published previously, and not under consideration for publication elsewhere, in whole or in part.
All the authors listed have approved the manuscript that is enclosed.
The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
